name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: Medicine

transcript.content: Hello, I'm Ricky Gervais.

As the Canadian physician William Osler once said, the desire to take medicine is perhaps the greatest feature, which distinguishes man from animals. From keyhole surgery to stem cell research, modern medicine enables the 20th century man to play God. But how did we get here? What incremental advances through the Ages gave birth to the medical wonders of today? Here to discuss the history and practice of medicine, are Stephen Merchant graduate from the University of Warwick and now award-winning writer.
Thank you very much indeed.
And Karl Pilkington. A man with no qualifications, very little education, but who is now known the world over as a shaven chimp with a head like a fucking orange.
Alright

Well there is obviously so much to discuss Ricky. I wondered in an effort, just to provoke some initial thoughts, if I can offer another quote from the great Carl Sagan. Who said: "Advances in medicine and agriculture have saved vastly more lives than have been lost in all the wars in history."
So quite a...
Just shows you shouldn't really worry about war.
What do you mean?
It's not a big problem, is it? Obviously So that's a good point there, Karl.
War's  not as bad as a lot of people make out. What do you think Karl? Overrated? Too much fuss about...
Well I don't know anyone who's died in a war, but I know loads of people have died from cancer and what have you.
So is that is that going on Carl's quote? Does that work?
Is he right? What did he say?!
Ricky bursts laughing
Good. Well, we're off to a fascinating start.

I think it'd be probably best Rick if we return to the very beginning of time. The dawn of man, because of course, even in primitive prehistoric ages medicine was practiced in some ways from the research people of done, cave paintings and the like. Karl, I wonder if you would just give us your initial thoughts on, you know the medicine of the ancient world.
You sound like you're if you haven't studied it, or you've been a be modest
You being modest?
Never really thought about it.
I mean they didn't have much. I know that Tutankhamun...
(mocking accent) Tutankhamuuun?
He died of like having a knee injury. So they didn't have that much medicine knocking about back then.
Right. Where do you get this information from? It sounds vague
I read it. I read it at an exhibition I went to.
Did you read the whole sentence or...?
No I just saw like, they had some video footage like made up, it wasn't from the time and they just sort of said this is probably what happened.
Sure. Did you put the headphones on and listen though, or you just guessed from the pictures?
I'm just looked because I couldn't have the headphones
(laughing) Sure, of course. Of course not.
Why couldn't you have the headphones?
They're just expensive.
How much?
About 50 Quid I think, deposit and everything.
Well, you get that back though when you return them. All you have to do is take them off your head and hand them in.
Well, I don't like the idea of handing money over because it's like when you get a flat and that, and you put a deposit in. You never get the full deposit back. I don't like deposits.
What do you think they're gonna do? They're going to take 50 quid off because you put wallpaper on your headphones?! It's not the same is it?
No, but it's a Tutankhamun exhibition.
So you're going to deprive yourself of education because you don't trust the National History Museum?
I didn't deprive me. I saw it, I saw this thing. He came off a chariot. They're dangerous things.
He came off a chariot?!
You saw that, how do you how he died? How could you tell from visual images that Tutankhamun died from a knee injury?
It's just... Honestly, you're going to make yourself look daft here, because that's what happened.
Imagine that! In a room with Karl Pilkington, and we make ourselves look daft. That would be incredible!
So aside from Tutankhamun's knee injury, that's pretty much your grasp of the ancient world of medicine?
Well, I don't know anyone else who's knocking about when...
What about if we go to sort of primitive man, cave dwelling man, what do you know there of medicine in their early stage?
Didn't really, didn't really bother.
Okay, is that guessing or...?
Wasn't the earliest ones people like Shaman? And  those tribal lords that would say... Well I assume even, you know, Pagan man had sort of Apothecarys, that dealt certain and roots and
Yeah, Shaman who would use herbs and so on. But of course, if we go back to primitive man you obviously familiar, I believe it's pronounced as it trepanning.
Oh, when you take the top of your head off and let out the demons

They found various skulls from ancient man, with holes bored in the top. Some of which had healed over suggesting that they had indeed drilled holes in their head or presumably they wouldn't have had drills in that point, crack the head and in their thinking, letting out evil spirits and then they healed back over. So, in some instances, the people survived.
Do you think it is fascinating that there was, there was a one point when man discovered that this thing that we now call the brain, which sort of houses the mind, he knew was in his head?
It's not that amazing.
Well, it's not to you because you know it's there.
But but back then I reckon, I'd know that's where it is.
Why? Can you feel where you're thinking?
Well, you just make sense to put it there.
Why?
When you think and you speak, it comes out your mouth, so just make sense that whatever is near that, is near to the mouth. If your brain was in foot it took ages for you to say anything.
Steve & Ricky both laugh
No it wouldn't! Why?
This is like actually talking to a primitive man about his understanding of medicine. They would have more insight. By this point they would have just cracked open your head to get the demons out.
Ricky laughs

Shall we move on to the ancient world in terms of Egyptians, the Greeks, the Romans. Of course because they made huge advances. Particularly the Romans, who understood of course the importance of sanitation. You know, famously their streets were clean.
Yeah. Don't you think that if we hadn't have cleaned up as much, that I don't know, we'd be stronger?
What?
Well, I know what you mean, yeah. They say to let your kids eat dirt
You know, it's immunity system. If you're too closeted you don't fight it... And you know that's exactly what immunization is, giving you a bit of the disease.
Yeah, but it's gone mental now. Whenever a baby's born is drugged out of his eyeballs.
What do you mean?
It's only about a week old and they give them all sorts of shots.
Like what?
Loads of stuff stuff. Stuff for whooping cough?
(mockingly) Yeah, you don't want 'ooping cough, Tutankhamuuun could have died of a 'ooping cough
No but, they give it loads of stuff and now it's like... I don't know it's making us weak.

Yeah. Soon there's going to be things that 1) we're not immune and 2) our antibiotics no longer work. Because of course, things like viruses and bacteria or whatever, they evolve and change so quickly that you can't keep up with them. And also there's this big thing, you know, like the Super Bug for example, there's a very strong theory that says that it's where people took half the course of antibiotics and what it did was, it was almost like an immunization to the bacteria and virus against the antibiotic.
They got stronger.
Yeah that's what I mean.

So yeah, we need some germs as you call them. But there are some that we have eradicated. I mean, I think it was in our lifetime that they eradicated smallpox from the world. They just stopped it and it saved I mean, millions and millions of lives, and they wiped out.
There are rumors of course that both Russia and America still have the smallpox virus under lock and key, which they could theoretically breed and use in a chemical warfare situation.

Well there was a bit of a scandal a few years ago, I think 10 years ago, where in a university laboratory, someone came across a marked yogurt pot in deep freeze that had smallpox in it. That was a hangover from the seventies
When you say it was marked, was it like someone's put their name on it because they don't want someone to eat their smallpox yogurt?
No no no, I think they looked into it and it was the deep frozen smallpox virus.
They just let it in the fridge?
Well I think so yeah it was an admin problem.
I'm sure that somewhere, what I mean is it's under lock and key or frozen up
Well that's not good enough is it? Under lock & key and that. It's not good enough, get rid of it! Why are they keeping a little tub of smallpox knocking about?
Well, they are they not, they're not meant to be.

What's it doing there in the first place? That's to me that's like in James Bond where they don't kill him when they have the chance. There's always that little thing of " Oh, let's play with danger! Let's keep a bit!"
Yeah.
Pop it next to AIDS in the Kia-Ora bottle.
Ricky laughs
I don't understand why store that?
Well there's probably a presumption is probably moving from the cold war, where people were thinking "Well, listen, what if Russia still got some smallpox, we better hang onto some smallpox"
It's just clutter though as well. We're obsessed with keeping stuff, and it's the same with germs: We can't even say "Get rid of that, we won't be needing it"
Smallpox: We'll keep it just in case, get rid of it!
Ricky & Steve both laugh
We've got this obsession thing again, it's saving everything. It's like always save every animal, even a germ. We get upset about if it dies out.

Yeah, but you say that but of course famously Alexander Fleming discovered what may be the most important breakthrough of the 20th century, which was the first antibiotic I think in 1928 and he's literally saved hundreds of millions of lives with that, changed the face of modern medicine. And he discovered that because he left bit of old bread out for a while and it went all moldy in his kitchen. And he was like "oh what's that? Oh, let's have a look!"
Like I've said to you before, it's down to him being scruffy more than anything. It just seems like there's a lot of scruffy kitchens around
You think his cleaner would come in and gone
"Oh, Mr. Fleming! Oh, you so you disgust me, you fucking, filthy scruffy cunt! I'm going to throw this bread away!"

He'd go: "Oh, Maud? Would you do with that old bread I left out? It had gone green Sir, so I chucked it away. Oh Maud! You dopey fucking slut! You just caused millions and millions of people to die. Keep out of my fucking kitchen!
I know, but don't put it there!
It's the same way smallpox, in a yogurt pot. It's in a yogurt pot! You're asking for trouble.
But what if Maud did come in and thrown that away, again?
You couldn't shout at her.
She's doing a job. I'd be annoyed if it was still there.
Yeah, so

It's been here now for a couple weeks, you aren't even asked. There's a lot of cleaners, that's that's part of the problem I'd say the cleaners. They're not doing the job. That's a problem in hospitals innit?
Yeah
There's filth everywhere.
Well they proved a point. In one hospital they bought a team of people in to show doctors and nurses how to clean things properly, and deaths went down 30%
There you go.
Just from properly washing your hands and properly washing the floor and things.
That's amazing, isn't it?
It's pretty simple, just don't put like yogurt pots with smallpox in the fridge. I mean that's a starter.
Yeah, but you were saying earlier, "Oh, let babies eat mud, don't inject them. Let them crawl around a dirty floor, clean up the floor, and no one would die!
I did say that, but we've gone too far now, babies are coming out marred. (groans) They can't handle anything now.
Come out what?
They're coming out all mardy.
All mardy?

Yeah, they get ill easy. Cause they're not tough babies anymore. We're ending up with a load of weak people who need looking after all the time, that costs a lot of money and they can't do anything. They're useless. Now, that doesn't happen in other nature. If a little weak bird is born you'll see Bill Oddie saying won't last
Ricky bursts laughing
He says, he says that won't last a week. And he's right, you watch it, and you know that third baby that came out it died.
But what's wrong point Karl? That modern medicine which can help people live to the age of 75-80 that he shouldn't be doing that? That they should let people just die off?
Well, here's something right?
The estate I grew up on. There's a woman there.
Yeah
Scruffy Sandra.
(laughs) Oh I like her already! It's great, it's so descriptive, she had no chance. Even if she cleaned up her act she'd come in looking like Pretty Woman, you'd go: "Alright Scruffy?"
What's the point, what is the point?
Fuckin' hell
So the thing is she used to always get on these buses called Dial-A-Rides, that was sort of like Posh taxes. You could call for one it, come round to your house.
Yeah
And it would pick you up and you pay like 50p
But it would pick up a bunch of other people as well.
Yeah yeah, on the way. So it would take ages to get to where you're going.
Oh what a nightmare that is.

No, it's good though. Kind of a bit of a day out, old people used to love it because you get to see things and you dare a call coming in on the radio that, you know, Scruffy Sandra is being picked up and you go "Oh God!" And she'd always have loads of bin bags with her for some reason. Now, the thing is...
Well, she sounds clean.
No, she stunk.
Well, she's taken out the bin bags.
Was she homeless?
No, she wasn't homeless she's used to just... She just didn't bath and that, she just stunk. But the weird thing is...
Why they didn't call her Stinky Sandra?
She never was ill.
Right.
People didn't sit next to her
Yeah
Because she stunk. Now, because of that, anyone who might have had a bit of flu or a cold, never sat next to Scruffy Sandra
Right
Because she stunk. But that was good. That was like a protection thing for her. Because she knew that because she stunk, no one wants to sit next to her. She wouldn't pick up the the germ.
Right. But this is quite... Your point is in order to fend off illness, you have to not bathe and so you stink.
So you're saying that it wasn't that she built up an immunity, it was that she stank so much that flu wouldn't come near her.
Steve laughs
This is such a specific example. It's not applicable in any other scenario.

There's always cold. There's always flew. Its whether you're immunity is is good or bad. The times I get ill are usually after like you know, a long-haul flight or something, when you're surrounded by it, and you're run down a little bit.
Maybe if you didn't bathe for three days before the flight.

Yeah. So, you know, it's always there, colds and flus everywhere. That's interesting, isn't it? That more sort of colds are spread through shaking hands than people, you know, just taking in the air. Because people sneeze into their hand and they think that's sort of safer, than they shake hands and you get it on your hand and it sort of dies in the air quickly. But it stays on your skin a bit more because it's you know, you're nice and warm lovely environment. So that's why some sort of germaphobes don't even shake hands anymore.
Yeah, that's going too far, because they're going to die of something. You can't be that paranoid. Gotta get on with your life
Loneliness
And it's good to feel ill because when you feel better, you appreciate how good you feel
Doesn't make any sense at all, "It's good to feel" It doesn't make any sense, go on.
No, it does afterwards. The other weekend, when I was a lad, I don't know what was up with me, but I got something
Symptoms?
Went to the toilet a lot. Felt sick at the same time, got a sweat on, felt weak,  had the shakes.
Just to bug yeah.
Lasted probably about
24 hours? After that 24 hours you go "Ah, feeling good again" And it's nice to feel good again, and it makes you appreciate how good you feel. Now Sometimes, I don't know if I feel well.
Doesn't make any sense either.
What do you mean sometimes you don't know whether you feel well?
Because I've been in my body for years
Ricky laughs
There he goes again! There he goes again, the two minds...
If there was some sort of kit that the doctor said: "How are you feeling Mr. Pilkington? I think of feel alright. Well, do you?"

They go: "Well, step into the machine" right? Get into the machine and if he could somehow transfer my feeling into his body so I could feel how he feels and then he can feel how I feel, and he will go: "Well, you're not well at all. Your heartbeat's irregular for a start."
You are maniac.
This is... I don't know what's going on here...
Why can't you just accept that if you feel well, you know...
Because you don't know if you feel well
Hang on, let's get this machine built. Sorry, why are people bothering studying AIDS? We got to get this machine built.
Listen, this machine could do a lot of good if they could do it.
Why?
Because some people you are about people who go "Oh, I think I've got a bit pf wind." Before you know, it they drop down dead, right? Because they didn't know.

They just... "Well didn't, Mr. Mr. Jones have a sweat on Mrs. Jones before he... Oh, yeah he did. But he always had a sweat on. Well, didn't it bother him? No he was used to it, happened for years. Why didn't you come in? Oh I felt alright.
So what would the machine do again?
The machine would make my doctor feel like me. It'd be sat there and it'd go...
Sorry, who's saying to Mrs. Jones that didn't Mr. Jones, have a sweat on?
The doctor.
So, the doctor knew he had a sweat on. Why didn't the doctor say let's have a look at that.
No, he's asking Mrs. Jones
He's not a very good doctor though is he? He's not a very good doctor then
This is the problem now, innit? Because there are too many ill people
So Mr. Jones went the doctor and said "Oh I've got a sweat on" right?

Right, so he'd go. "Hhhmm. Well I tell you what, get in the machine." So Mr. Jones, gets in the machine. The doctor hits the button. Mr. Jones gets into the doctor. The doctor goes: "You have got a sweat on, I'm familiar with this because I had a fella in the other day with the similar thing. Take three of these.
You are a mental case. I don't know what that... I don't know what this is.
But why can't the doctor make that observation like a doctor does? Why can't the doctor using his knowledge observe the person with the sweat on?
I'll tell you why
This is like a scene from Ghost. This is like Patrick Swayze
Listen. Do you know about that time when I went to the doctor's and he said my nerves are too short?'
Steve laughs
That doesn't make any sense at all
I told you about it and I don't want to go through that again. But he looked at me legs and stretched them and said, "yeah it's the old short nerves problem."
Ricky laughs
The old famous short nerves problem.
That took like three visits before he work that out.
But how would it be able to... Just because he was feeling how you feeling that wouldn't help him identify.

Yeah, they're in your body. You're not going "Bloody hell, me nerves are a bit short" You're going to the doctor: "okay and we're just gonna place Mr. Pilkington ~imitates machine~ "Ah Pilkington is in me. Me nerves are too short!"
When me nerves were short
Have they extended since then?
Well, the I just have to do stretches. Just pull them.
But when I-- when I had that, I'm not very good with words.
Go on.
So when I was going in saying, "Doctor, me knee's aching," uh, and he'd go, "What sort of ache is it?" Well I don't know.
Yeah.
I don't know, I-I've-- it's just an ache--
Toothache, it's like a toothache in my leg--
No, but it's different.
Go on.
It's a different ache. Now the thing is--
Arse ache, it's like an arse ache!
It's hard to explain an ache.
Yeah.
So he'd have to feel the ache and then he could make an assumption on it.
Thank you.
So he would presumably go through training going in the machine and they bring in various sick people and he would experience and feel every single ailment.
Great.
Yeah. But over--
[As the nurse] Doctor, I'm gonna let you know now what a swift kick in the bollocks feels like just in case you ever have to diagnose that... [As the doctor] Oh you cunt! OK, I'll remember that one.
Yeah but--
[As the nurse] Doctor, now you're going to feel a spike up the arse.
Steve laughs
It's all about--
[As the doctor] Oh OK, I'll remember that one, OK! [As the nurse] Doctor--
[As the doctor] Now, couldn't I just wait until a man comes in with a spike up the arse?
[As the nurse] No, no. We've got to tell you so you- so you know when you feel it--
[As the doctor] But I reckon I could assess it if he's come in and he's got the spike up his arse, I could tell--
No no no no no no no no. You've got to experience everything before someone comes in and gets into your body like 'Ghost' and then you'll know what it is.
Hey listen, let's not- let's not dismiss this idea of hand of course, because you'll famously remember, uh Rick, that Karl had the idea of a man who can grow backwards. So he's born as an old man--
Yeah.
-and when he dies he's a young baby. I think we're all looking forward to the new Brad Pitt film--
Hmm...
-that is exactly that plot.
Well...
Bit strange.
It's not really strange, is it? Because it's from a novel, uh, I think written before Karl was born.
That's true. That is true. So actually--
But I haven't read it, so--
Well, that's obvious.
-just an idea. And with all ideas come something. Einstein said that. He said if a- if an idea isn't, uhh...
Go on.
What did Einstein say?
W-w-w-w-w-wait, just let him finish. We've got an Einstein quote here.
Yeah.
This is a historic day. Um, Karl, sorry, what were you saying? What did- what did uh, what did, uh, Albert Einstein say?
He just said something along the lines of...
No no no no..
Well, no no no- give us the quote.
Go on, do it properly
Well it doesn't matter--
No no no--
-about how he worded it, it's the point in hand--

Well I think it is. I think a quote is- I think, like all, you know, an-any sort of, uh uh uhh, poetic content of anything is exactly how it's- how it's worded. So just what did- what did Einstein say exactly?
It's not at all.
Well yeah, it is, yeah.
Well, he said something along the lines of--
Go on...
Uh, an idea- if an idea isn't daft--
Oh, start again, start again.
No, come on, let's hear it.
No 'cause he start- h-h-he- faltered--
He said "If an idea isn't daft, it isn't worth thinking about."
What? Say it again.
"If an idea isn't daft, it isn't worth thinking about."
I can't imagine him saying 'daft.'
No, I can't, I can't.
Well it was something al- like that though, meaning that every new idea seems a bit mental.
Yeah.
Right?
It's a good point.
But then it leads to something.
Hmm, I'm not sure that he would--
Well, well, no, no...
But I think if we were sat with Einstein now and you'd brought up the machine that allows doctors to feel, I don't think he'd be saying we should pursue that idea.

No. There's some ideas that go [Mumbles] "I think the Earth might be round," and people go "Oh you're an idiot, it's flat." And then there's people who stand in doorways covered in crucifixes with, um, tinfoil on their head saying "Jesus is in my cock."
Yeah, but--
Now, he's a mentalist.

Yes, but what I'm saying is wouldn't you have said it was mental years ago when someone said "I'm going to make a machine so I can look inside your head"? Years on: "Hello, get in the machine, we've got an MRI scanner."
Ricky laughs
It's the next one along.
They'd go: "Why are you looking in their head?" That's where the brain is.
I'll tell you what: we've got similar to it anyway? Because I've read about this machine, where... right, say if put it on Steve, right?
Go on
I wear a camera on me head
Right. If this is going to be "I can see Steve's thoughts"
No but it's similar to that and and it works as well. So I put a camera on Steve's head
Mmmm, okay, it's changed already. Who's head is the camera on?
I don't think it matters.
Okay, fine
Okay okay,
Just explain it.
I put a camera on Steve's head. I've got a camera on Steve's head. What I've got on my head are some goggles.
Right
Over your eyes?
Yep
You've got the camera. Through my goggles I'm seeing, what your camera is seeing.
And where is the camera? Is it looking out from my eyes?
Yeah.
So basically, you can see what I can see?
So I'm seeing what you see.
But couldn't you just stand where I'm standing?
Well that's just a monitor. That happens now, you can all see the same image.
Hang on.
Long pause
How's it work now?

Well, we'll wait, we'll wait. This is... You're at the Royal College of Surgeons your presenting, this idea. Now, everyone in the world is sat down here, the eminent scientist are going "Karl Pilkington is a genius, he's got an idea for cameras and goggles."
Now you're saying this already exists.
This this is just come out the other week.
Oh okay
Put a camera on Steve's eyes, he sees he sees through the camera.
What do you mean? Why is he seeing through a camera? I don't know what you mean.
Wherever he looks, the camera's looking.
Okay, so it's a camera, right okay, yeah.
It's a camera on his head.
He's not seeing through it, it just sees what he's seeing because it's because it's pointing in exactly the same direction as he does.
Yeah, if he turns his head to the right, I'll see it
So you're seeing... you're looking at monitor really.
Right. So one of the simplest ideas, but it's taken us 20 minutes to explain it. Okay, go on?
So it's same as a cameraman pointing in the camera anywhere, we're watching the telly. We're seeing what the cameraman sees, basically. Go on then. You just invented television, well done.
Okay, so I've got the camera on my head, it's seeing what I'm seeing. Go! You've got goggles on your eyes.
I've got goggles on. If you turn right, I feel like I'm turning right.
Okay, right?
Now my brain gets a point that if you wear it for long enough, that brain thinks it's you. Because what happens is
What?!
Because the brains being kidded. At the end of the day, my brain thinks it's seen everything because my eyes are looking at stuff.
Yeah, that's true, that's true, but it doesn't think I'm Steve Merchant. It experiences what Steve's seeing this like a virtual reality.

No, but that's the weird thing. If you wear it for long enough, the brain sort of seeing it like Steve's arm go up to his head and scratch it and it gets to a point where the brain feels a scratch, even though it's not scratching my head. So they say in this is like you kidding your brain basically.
I can see how that would work.
But you're not going to believe that you're me
No, you're not going to believe you're Steve Merchant.
You not gonna start experiencing life as I experience it.
Me brain would.
What do you mean your brain would, but you wouldn't?!
Ricky laughs
We've done this, Steve! We've done this.
Because I'm kidding the brain.
Yes, but you couldn't kid it into thinking you're me, you wouldn't forget that you're Karl, wearing a Contraption.
But what I was saying is, if someone went up to your stomach and start tickling you, my brain would look down and see that someone who's tickling me?
Yes.
Yeah.
And I'd start laughing.
I can understand you might
No, you wouldn't. Well, yeah, you might do because it might be a confusing stimulus.
But the point is, there may be certain physical things which you experience through it, but you're not going to stop thinking "Hang on, I'm Karl, wearing the mask." are you?
No
But you can do that!
You're thinking you're Karl, seeing all the things that actually Steve does
-mumbling- What, you think your memory's gonna change? You not gonna remember your name or remember Suzanne's name? What are you talking about?
No, but say if we did that that event with a load of students in front of us? I'd remember that day through your eyes.
Yeah.
So I would be living in your head.
Yeah, but you would be also aware that you're wearing a contraption.
Yeah
You wouldn't remember it as being "Oh, I was Steve Merchant for a day"
But I kind of was!
But look! Karl, listen!
I sat down and we watched the same thing. We watched a bit of Brokeback Mountain, and we all have different thoughts.
Yeah, because we're all sat in different places.

No, no roughly speaking, we had the same experience when we're looking at the same thing, but it doesn't mean you assess it the same way, doesn't mean, you understand it the same way and it doesn't mean you apply the knowledge in the same way.
No, I understand that but
It's an interesting experiment, it is interesting. It would be interesting to see it live. You're actually living... It's a different window to the world.

Well yes, I say if I was a fella with no arms and legs but these goggles are the really long lead, and you went about living your day, and I was looking through your eyes. I could have quite an interesting life...
Yes, you could, but you couldn't stop remembering that you're the person wearing the contraption.
...without the hassle.
And also
But also, what is life? Life is what you experience.
But no, but no. If Steve went off... but you know this wouldn't you?
But would you? If you stuck one on a baby?

Well, yeah that's different. Yeah. I mean if a baby knew no different and those were his experience, then he would be feeling what he thought he was. Then there'd be, there'd be nothing. But then you know, let's face it, tickling someone is the sensation. It's not the thought, it's not the concept of being tickled is funny.
No it's not though, because if someone goes to tickle you, but they don't tickle you, you can actually laughs can't you? Because you go "Ah God, I know what the feeling is going to be like"
